titleStmt.author: Shirley, James, 1596-1666.

note.p: "Presented at Salisbury court by Her Majesties servants."
Reproduction of original in Bristol Public Library, Bristol, England.

div.p: THE POLITITIAN, A TRAGEDY, Presented at Salisbury Court BY HER MAIESTIES SERVANTS;
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moseley and are to be sold at his Shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Church-yard. 1655.

div.head: To the very much Honored WALTER MOYLE, Esq
div.p: THough the severity of the times took away those dramatique recreations (whose language so much glorified the English Scene) and perhaps looking at some abuses of the common Theaters, which were not so happily purg'd from scurrility, and under-wit, (the onely entertainment of vulgar Capacities) they have outed the more noble and ingenious actions of the eminent stages; The rage yet hath not been Epidemicall, there are left many lovers of this exiled Posie, who are great Masters of reason, and that dare conscientiously own this musicall part of Humane learning, when it is presented without the staines of impudence and profanation.

Among these persons, sir you deserve an honorable inscription. For my own part; this is the last which is like to salute the publique view in this
kind, and I have onely to say, that I Congratulate my own happiness to conclude with so judicious a Patron.

To make a doubt of your fair receiving this piece: were to dishonor your Character, and make my self undeserving. Read at your leisure, what is humbly presented to your eye and judgment, while I preserve my confidence in your vertue and good thoughts upon

closer.signed: The most humble honorer of your worth JAMES SHIRLEY

div.head: The names and small Characters of the Persons.

list.item: KIng of Norway, easie and credulous in his nature, and passionately doting upon Queen Marpisa.
Gotharus, the polititian, active to serve his pleasures and ambition, a great favorite of the Queen.
Turgesius, the Prince, of a gallant disposition, and honoured by the souldier.
Duke Olaus, the Kings Uncle, old, cholerique and distast'd with the Court-proceedings, disaffected to Gotharus, and the Queen, but resolute, and faithfull to the Prince.
Haraldus Son to Marpisa, young, of a sweet and noble disposition, whom Gotharus would form more bold, and ambitious for the greatness he had design'd.
Sueno, Helga a couple of Court-Parasites.
Marpisa the Queen, a 'proud subtle and revengefull Lady, from the widow of Count Altomarus, advanc'd to royall condition, by the practise of her creature and confident, Gotharus.
Albina, wife to Gotharus a vertuous but suffering Lady, under the tyranny of an imperious, and disloyall husband.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: IT was a strange and suddaine marriage.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Could he not love her for the game, and so forth,
But he must thus exalt her? no lesse title
Then Queen, to satisfie her ambition?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Tis a brave rise!

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I did not prophesie,
When the honest Count her husband Altomarus
Liv'd, she would bring us on our knees.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I hope
She'l love the King for't.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: And in his absence,
Gotharus the Kings Minion, her old friend,
He has done this royall service; beside, what
Rests on accompts in her old husbands dayes.
I do suspect her Son Haraldus was
Got with more heat, and blood, then Altomarus
Age could assure her, but hee's dead.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: — Be with him;
Although I wo'not make oath for her chastity,
That boyes good nature is an argument
To me, Gotharus had no share in him:
Hee's honest, of a gentle disposition,
And on my Conscience does pray sometimes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No more, we have a Wolfe by'th' eare, what news
From Hell? he cannot want intelligence, he has
So many friends there— he's displeas'd, there is
Some goodness in that Letter, I will pawne
My head, that makes him angry.
sp.stage: Enter some with Petitions, Gotharus frowns upon 'em, they returne hastily.
sp.l: How his frown
Hath scatterrd 'em like leaves, they fly from him
As nimbly, as their bodyes had no more weight
Then their Petitions; I would give an eye-tooth,
To read but three lines.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Curse upon his victory!
I meant him not this safety, when I wrought
The King to send him forth to warre, but hop'd
His active spirit would have met some engine
To have translated him to another world;
He's now upon return. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would I had but
The harrowing of your skull; my genius gives me▪
That Paper is some good news of the Prince,
I would I knew it but concern'd him.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Twas
My wonder, the King would send his Son abroad
To warres, the onely pledge of his succession.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He had a Councellor, this Polititian,
That would prefer the Prince to Heaven, a place
His Lordship has no hope to be acquainted with;
The Prince, and his great Uncle Duke Olaus,
Would not allow these pranks of State, nor see
The King betrai'd to a Concubine;
Therefore it was thought fit they should be engag'd
To forraigne dangers.
sp.stage: Enter Albina, and her waiting woman.
sp.l: 'Tis Madam Albina,
Our great mans wife.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: The King did seem to affect her,
Before he married her to his favorite.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Dost think she's honest?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Ile not stake my soul on't,
But I believe she is too good for him,
Although the King and she have private conference.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: She looks as she were discontent. Exit Al.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: She has cause
In being Gotharus wife, some say she lov'd him
Most passionately.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: 'Twas her destiny;
She has him now, and if she love him still,
'Tis not impossible she may be a Martyr,
His proud and rugged nature will advance
Her patience too't.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Avoid the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The King is coming, oh my Lord, your pardon:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Nay we must all obey.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I near lik'd
This fellow.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: He is one of fortunes Minions▪
The love of the choice Ladyes of the Landry,
That's one that draws in the same team, but more
Inclin'd to'th Knave; he is a kind of Pendant
To the Kings ear, an everlasting parasite:
The King? Albina return'd with him. Exit.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Leave us.
Y'are most unkind to your self in my opinion,
You know well who I am, and what I have
Advanc'd you too; neither in virgin state
Nor marriage, to allow your King a favour?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sir, let the humble duty of a subject,
Who shall with zealous prayers solicite heaven
For you, and your fair Queen—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Had you been wise,
That might have been your Title, but the God
Of love had with his Arrow so engraven
Gotharus in your heart; you had no language
But what concern'd his praise, scarce any thought
At liberty; I did imagine, when
I had compassion of your sufferings,
And gave thee a fair Bride to my Gotharus,
You would not lose the memory of my benefit,
But (now in state, and nature to reward it)
Consented to returne me love.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Be pleas'd
To excuse the boldnesse of one question.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be free Albina.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Do not you love my husband?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: There wants no testimony, beside the rest,
My giving thee to him, dear to my thoughts,
Is argument I love him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Would you take
Me back agen? you but betraid his faith,
And your own gift, to tempt me to forsake him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: You are more apprehensive, if you please
He shall possesse you still, I but desire
Sometimes a neere and loving conversation,
Though he should know't, considering how much
I may deserve, he would be wise enough
To love thee near the worse; he's not the first
Lord that hath purchas'd offices by the free
Surrender of his wife to the Kings use,
'Tis frequent in all common-wealths to lend
Their play-fellows to a friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Oh do not think
Gotharus can be worth your love, to be
So most degenerate, and lost to honour;
You have a Queen, to whom your vow is sacred,
Be just to her, the blessing is yet warm
Pronounc'd by holy Priest, stain not a passion
To wander from that beauty, richer far
Then Mine; let your souls meet and kiss each other,
That while you live, the examples of chaste love
(Most glorious in a King and Queene) we may
Grow up in vertue by the spring of yours,
Till our top-boughs reach heaven.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: You are resolved then
We must be strangers, should my life depend
On the possession of your bosome, I
Should languish and expire, I see.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Good heaven
Will not permit the King want so much goodness,
To think the enjoying of forbidden pleasure
Could benefit his life, rather let mine
Ebbe at some wound, and wander with my blood
By your command ta'ne from me, on my knee—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Rise, I may kiss Albina—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ha! Enter Gotharus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Thas shot
Another flame into me, come you must—

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Be a woman, do't, or ile complain.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Thy husband.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Horror!

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Think upon't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What will become of miserable Albina?
Like a poor Deere pursu'd to a steep precipice,
That overlooks the Sea, by some fierce hound;
The Iust of a wild King doth threaten here,
Before me, the neglects of him I love,
Gotharus my unkind Lord, like the waves,
And full as deafe affright me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How now Madam?
Come, can you kiss?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Kiss sir?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What difference
Between his touch and mine now? his perhaps
Was with more heat, but mine was soft enough.
What has he promis'd thee, but that's no matter,
Thou wo't be wise enough to make thy bargain,
I father all, onely the King shall give it
A name, he'l make it master of a Province.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What means my Lord:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou thinkst I am jealous now, not I, I knew
Before he doated on thee, and it is
To be presum'd, having a veile to hide
Thy blushes, (I do mean our marriage)
Thou maist find out some time to meet, and mingle
Stories and limbs, it may be necessary;
And 'cause I will be dutifull to the King,
We will converse no more abed, ile be
Thy husband still Albina, and weare my buds
Under my haire close like a prudent Statesman;
But 'twere not much amisse, as I advis'd
Before, and these new premises consider'd,
You appear abroad with a less train, your Wardrobe
Will make you more suspected, if it be
Too rich; and some whole dayes to keepe your Chamber,
Will make the King know where to find you certain.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Will you have patience my Lord to hear me?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The world doth partly think thee honest too,
That will help much, if you observe good rules
And dyet, without tedious progresses,
And visiting of Ladyes, expert in
Night Revels, Masks, and twenty other torments
To an estate; your Doctors must be left too,
I wo'not pay a fee to have your pulse
Felt, and your hand roll'd up like wax, by one
Whose footcloth must attend, while he makes leggs,
And every other morning comes to tell
Your Ladyship a story out of Aretine,
That can set you a longing for diseases,
That he may cure you, and your waiting-woman,
Whose curiosity would taste your Glister,
Commend the operation from her stomack.
Should you be sick, and sick to death, I wo'd
Not counsell you to physick; women are
Fraile things, and should a cordiall miscarry,
My conscience would be arraign'd, and I
Might be suspected for your poisoner.
No, no, I thank you, y'are in a fine course
To ease me wife; or if you must be loose,
I'th spring and fall, let the King bear the charges.
He will, if you apply your selfe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am wretched;
Why do you without hearing thus condemn me?
The Lady lives not with a purer faith
To her lov'd Lord, then I have; nor shall greatness,
Nor death it selfe, have power to break it.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Come,
These are but painted teares, leave this, have you
Prepar'd your last accompts?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: They are ready sir;
Never was Lady slav'd thus like Albina,
A stipendary, worse, a servile steward,
To give him an accompt of all my expences.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I'le have it so in spight of customes heart,
While you are mine; accountless liberty
Is ruine of whole families: now leave me, Exit Al.
We may talk more anon, I have observ'd
This privacy before, search here Gotharus,
'Tis here from whence mutinous thoughts conspiring
With witty melancholly, shal beget
A strong born mischiefe, I'le admit she be
Honest, I love her not, and if he tempt her
To sinne, that's paid him back in his wives loosness;
From whom I took my first ambition,
And must go on, till we can sway the Kingdom,
Though we clime to't o're many deaths. I first
Practise at home, my unkindness to Albina,
If she do love me must needs break her heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My honour'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Most dear Haraldus welcome,
Preciously welcome to Gotharus heart.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The Queen my mother, sir, would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How excellently do those words become thee,
'Tis fit Haraldus Mother be a Queene,
Th'art worth a princely fate; I will attend her.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ile tell her so.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis not an office for you.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: It is my duty sir, to wait upon
My mother.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Who i'th Court is not your servant?
You doe not exercise command enough,
You are too gentle in your fortunes sir,
And weare your greatnesse, as you were not born
To be a Prince.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My birth sure gave me not
That title, I was born with the condition
To obey, not govern.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Do not wrong those Starres,
Which early as you did salute the world,
Design'd this glorious fate; I did consult,
And in the happy minute of thy birth,
Collect what was decreed in heaven about thee.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Those books are 'bove my reading, but what E're
my stars determine of me, 'tis but late
I heard my mother say, you are on earth,
To whom I am most bound for what I am:

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis a shrewd truth, if thou knew'st all.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You have
Been more a father then a friend to us.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Friend to thy Mother, I confess in private,
The other followes by a consequence, aside.
A father my Haraldus? I confess
I was from thy nativity inclin'd
By a most strange and secret force of nature,
Or sympathy to love thee like my owne;
And let me tell thee, though thy mother had
Merit enough to engage my senses;
Yet there was something more in thee consider'd,
That rais'd my thoughts, and study to advance
Thee to these pregnant hopes of state, methinks
I see thee a King already.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Good sir, do not
Prompt me to that ambition, I possess
Too much already, and I could, so pleas'd
My Mother, travell where I should not hear
Of these great titles, and it comes now aptly,
I should entreat your Lordship to assist me
In a request to her, I know she loves you,
And will deny you nothing; I would faine
Visit the University for study,
I do lose time methinks.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Fie Haraldus,
And leave the Court? how you forget your selfe?
Study to be King,
I shall halfe repent my care,
If you permit these dull and phlegmatick
Thoughts to usurpe, they'l stifle your whole reason,
Catch at the Sunne, devest him of his beame,
And in your eye wear his proud rayes; let day
Be when you smile, and when your anger points,
Shoot death in every frowne: covet a shade,
Affect a solitude, and books, and forfeit,
So brave an expectation?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Of Norwayes Crown.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Could there be any thought
Within me so ambitious, with what hope
Could it be cherished, when I have no title?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I that have thus farre studied thy fortune,
May find a way.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The King—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Is not immortal while he has Physitians.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What's that unsaid? The King is happy,
And the whole Nation treasure up their hopes
In Prince Turgesius, who with his great uncle
Valiant Olaus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Are sent to'th warres, where 'twill concerne 'm,
To think of fame, and how to march to honour
Through death.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not hear him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Or if they
Return—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: They will be welcome to all good
Mens hearts, and next the King, none with more joy
Congratulate their safeties, then your selfe:
I am confident my Lord you will remember
To see my Mother, and excuse me if
To finish something else I had in charge,
I take my leave, all good dwell with your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But that I have Marpisas faith, I could
Suspect him not the issue of my blood,
He is too tame, and honest, at his yeers
I was prodigiously in love with greatnesse;
Or if not mine, let him inherit but
His Mothers soule, she has pride enough, and spirit
To catch at flames, his education
Has been too soft, I must new form the boy
Into more vice, and daring, strange, we must
Study at Court, how to corrupt our Children▪
The Queene!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My expectation to speak
With thee Gotharus, was too painfull to me;
I feare we are all undone; dost hear the news?
The Prince is comming back with victory,
Our day will be o're-cast.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These eyes will force
A brighter from those clouds; are not you Queene?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: But how Turgesius, and his bold uncle
Wil look upon me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let 'em stare out
Their eyeballs, be you mistress still of the
Kings heart, and let their gall spout in their stomack,
We'l be secure.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Thou art my fate.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I must confesse
I was troubled when I heard it first; seem not
You pale at their return, but put on smiles
To grace their triumph; now you have most need
Of womans art, dissemble cunningly.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: My best Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: They shall find stratagems in peace, more fatal
Then all the Engines of the war; what mischiefe
Will not Gotharus fly to, to assure
The fair Marpisa's greatness, and his own,
In being hers (an Empire 'bove the world)
There is a heaven in either eye, that calls
My adoration, such Promethean fire,
As were I struck dead in my works, shouldst thou
But dart one look upon me, it would quicken
My cold dust, and informe it with a soul
More daring then the first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Still my resolv'd Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let weak Statesmen think of conscience,
I am arm'd against a thousand stings, and laugh at
The tales of Hell, and other worlds, we must
Possess our joyes in this, and know no other
But what our fancy every minute shall
Create to please us.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This is harmony,
How dull is the Kings language, I could dwell
Upon thy lips; why should not we engender
At every sense?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Now you put me in mind,
The pledge of both our hopes, and blood, Haraldus,
Is not well bred, he talks too morally,
He must have other discipline, and be fashion'd
For our great aims upon him; a Crown never
Became a Stoick, pray let me commend
Some conversation to his youth.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He is thine. Enter Helga.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: He shall be every way my own.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: The King desires your presence Madam.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I attend, you'l follow— Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thee to death, and triumph in
My ruines for thy sake, a thousand forms
Throng in my braine, that is the best, which speeds,
Who looks at Crowns, must have no thought who bleeds. Exit.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: THis musick doth but add to melancholly,
Ile hear no more.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He's strangely mov'd.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I cannot think a cause,
You were wont to fool him into mirth; Where's Helga
Your dear companion? no device between you
To raise his thoughts?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I am nothing without my fellow,
Musick is best in Consort.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Your buffonry is musical belike.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Your Juglers cannot do some o'their tricks
Without confederacy.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I'le try alone.
If please your Majesty there is—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: That for your unseasonable and saucie fooling. strikes him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That was a musical box o'th' ear.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Leave us.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: 'Tis nothing without a fellow, he knows
Musick is best in Consort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Would you had your parts?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hormenus you may stay.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Men do account thee honest.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: 'Tis possible
I May fare the worse.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: And wise; canst tell the cause why I am sad?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Nor I my self, 'tis strange I should be subject
To a dull passion, and no reason for it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: These things are frequent.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Sometimes ominous,
And do portend.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: If you enjoy a health,
What is in fate?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I am King
Still, and I not?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We are all happy in't,
And when time shall with the consent of nature,
Call you an old man from this world to heaven,
May he that shall suceed you, Prince Turgesius,
The glory of our hope, be no less fortunate.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: My Son,
I was too rash to part with him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We should
Have thought his stay a blessing, and did wish
You would not have expos'd such tender years
To the rough warre; but your commands met with
His duty, and our obedience.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: It is very
Strange, we of late hear no success, I hope
This sadnesse is not for his loss, he has
A kinsman with him, loves him dearly, 'tis
The Queen. Enter Queen and Helga.
I feel my drooping thoughts fall off,
And my clouds fly before the wind, her presence
Hath an infusion to restore dead nature.
My sweet, my dear Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You sent for me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I am but the shadow of my selfe without thee.
No wonder I was sad, my soul had plac'd
All her delight in these fair eyes, and could not
But think it selfe an exile in thy absence,
Why should we ever part, but chaine our selves
Together thus?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: He's in a better humour I hope;
I do not think but his Majestie would cuffe well,
His hand carryes a princely weight.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: A favour.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Would you might weare such another in your eare.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Come hither— on this side.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You were on that side before.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: wo'dst not thou lose thy life, to do a service
My Queen would smile upon?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Alas, My life
Is the least thing to be imagin'd, he
Is not a faithful subject would refuse
To kill his wife and children, after that
To hang himselfe, to do the Queen a service.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Come hither Helga.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Royal sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What would affright thy undertaking, to deserve
The least grace from my Queen?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
But I've an opinion, the Devill could not;
My life is nothing fir, to obtaine her favour,
I would hazard more; I have heard talk of hell,
So farre she should command me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Bless me goodness!
What wretched Parasites are these? how can
The King be patient at 'em? here is flattery
So thick and grosse, it would endure a hand-saw.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: His judgement's I fear stupified.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come hither,
Which of you can resolve, what serpent spawn'd you?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You are pleasant.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: My good Lord, it hurts not you,
There is necessity of some knaves, and so
Your Lordship be exempted, why should you
Trouble your selfe, and murmur at our courses?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Your businesse?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: News from the field.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: How prethee?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: The day, the field, the safety, O the glory
Of warre is Norwaies, Letters to the King—

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Give 'em to me.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Or me.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Trust not a fool with things of consequence,
He's the Kings mirth, let me present the news.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Sir, I should know you; this is a knave,
Would take to him all the glory of your report;
If please you, let me present the Letters.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: My Leige!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My Soveraigne!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: News!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good news!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Excellent newes!

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The Prince▪

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The Prince is—

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: The enemy is— o'rethrown.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: They have lost the day.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Defeated utterly.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: And are all slain.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Madam, will you hear the news?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Say on, what is't you would relate?

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: One of my creatures sir hath brought you Letters, Aquinus delivers the Letters.
My servant sir, one strengthened to your service
Out of my maintenance, an instrument of mine,
So please you to consider my duty in his service.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Why hark you Gentlemen, I have but mock'd
Your greedy zeals, there's no such matter in
Those Letters as you have told; we have lost all,
And the Prince taken prisoner, will you not
Stay for the reward, you know I'm but your Creature,
I look for nothing but your courtly faces
To pay my travel.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: We wo'not appear yet— Exit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: How the Rats vanish.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Read here my best Marpisa, news that makes
A triumph in my heart, great as the conquest
Upon our enemies; Hormenus, Cortes,
Our Son will prove a Souldier, was my sadnesse
Omen to this good fate? or nature fear'd
The extasie of my joy would else o'recome me?
They are return'd victorious.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thanks to heaven!

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: And some reward is due to thee; wear that
For the Kings sake.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You too much honour me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: But something in Marpisa's face, shews not
So clear a joy as we express, forbear, Exeunt.
Wait till we call; can this offend my Queen,
To hear of happinesse to my Son? O let
Thy eyes look bright, there shine hath force to make
The wreath of Laurel grow upon his temples;
Why dost thou weep? this dew will kill the victory,
And turn his Bay to Cipresse.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Witnesse heaven,
There's not a teare that mourns for him, his safety
And conquest is most welcome, and he shall
Have still my prayers, he may grow up in fame,
And all the glorious fortunes of a Prince:
But while my wishes fly to heaven for blessings
Upon his head, at the same time, I must
Remember in what miserable condition
My stars have plac'd me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What can make thy state
Guilty of such a name, and so deject
Thy nobler thoughts? am not I still the King?
And is not fair Marpisa mine by marriage?
Crown'd here my Queen immortally.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Though I be
By royall bounty of your love, possest
Of that great Title sir, I have some fears.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: You amaze me, speak thy doubts at large.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The Prince
(Dear to your love, and I still wish him so)
(Dear to your peoples hearts) I fear, will think
Our marriage his dishonour, and Olaus
Your passionate Uncle, no good friend of mine,
When he shall see to what a height your love
And holy vow hath rais'd me, most unworthy,
Will but salute Marpisa with his scorn,
And by his counsell, or some waies of force
Unchain our hearts, and throw me from your bosome
To death, or worse, to shame; oh think upon me,
And if you have one fear that's kin to mine,
Prevent their tyrannie, and give me doom
Of exile e're their cruelty arrive:
Ile take my sentence kindly from your lips,
Though it be killing.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Let my Son or Uncle,
Dare but affront three in a look, I shall
Forget the ties of nature, and discharge 'em
Like the corruption in my blood.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I can
Submit my selfe to them, and would you please
To allow my humblenesse no staine to what
You have advanc'd me to, I can be their servant,
And with as true a duty wait upon 'em—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Thou art all goodnesse, twenty Kingdoms are
Too little for thy dowry; who attends?
Thus every minute I will marry thee,
And wear thee in my heart, vanish the thought
Of all thy sex beside, and what can else
Attempt our separation: th'art obscure,
And liv'st in Court but like a masking star,
Shut from us by the unkindnesse of a cloud
When Cynthia goes to Revels: I will have
A chariot for my Queen richer then er'e
Was shewn in Roman triumph, and thou shalt
Be drawn with Horses white as Venus doves,
Till heaven it selfe in envy of our bliss,
Snatch thee from earth to place thee in his Orbe,
The brightest constellation.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: He dotes strangely.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hormenus, Cortes, I would have you all
Search your inventions to advance new joyes;
Proclaime all pleasures free, and while my fair
Queen smiles, it shall be death for any man
I'th Court to frown. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: You ha' not so much love i'th Court Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: How do you like the Queen?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Why she's not married,
He does but call her so.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And lyes with her.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: The Prince yet knows it not.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hee'l meet it coming home.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aquinus? Enter Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You brought Letters from the Camp.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I did my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What in the name of Policy is now hatching?
I do not like those fawning postures in him,
How kind they are.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That Souldier is thought honest.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But if he cringe once more I shall suspect him,
That leg confirms he is corrupt already.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How does he like his fathers marriage?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: We had no fame on't there when I set forth.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'T was strange and suddain, but we are all happy
In the good Princes health and victory;
The Duke Olaus too I hope is well.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He was design'd at my departure,
To be here before the Army.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He will be welcome:
You shall accept the price of a new Armour,
And wherein any power of mine can serve you
I'th Court, command.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I am your Lord-ships creature. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are gone, I long to see the Prince▪
How do you think his Highnesse will
Behave himself to his new mother Queen?
Will it be treason not to aske her blessing?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: I am confident his Uncle, brave Olaus.
Wo'not run mad for joy of the Kings marriage?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let them look to't, there may be alterations.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: They talk sure of my mother and the King.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Secure as they account themselves, the Prince
Must be receiv'd spight of Marpisa's greatnesse,
And all the tricks of her incarnate fiend
Gotharus, who both plot I fear, to raise
That Composition of their blood,
Haraldus—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: How was that?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The strange effect
Of their luxurious appetites, though in him
Poor innocence, suspecting not their sin,
We read no such ambition.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Oh my shame!
What have my ears receiv'd? am I a bastard?
'Tis malice that doth wound my Mothers honour;
How many bleed at once? yet now I call
To memory, Gotharus at our loving
Late conference, did much insult upon
The name of a Father, and his care of me
By some strange force of nature: ha! my fears
Shoot an Ice through me, I must know the truth
Although it kill me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Who was that Haraldus?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hope he did not hear us, again Gotharus.
And the two squirrels; more devices yet.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Let us alone my Lord, we'l quicken him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You must use all your art to win him to't.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Let us alone to make him drink, we are the credit
Of the Court for that, he's but a child alas, we'l take our time.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Hormenus.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My good Lord Olaus, I
Joy in your safe return, how fares the Prince?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Well, where's the King?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Kissing his new made Queen Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ha!
The King is married then. Exit Su. & Ho.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Away, the Duke Olaus, sir—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I am too stiffe for Complement,
My Lord, I have rid hard— Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He has met the intelligence,
And is displeas'd with me the state of things at home;
This marriage stings him, let it, we must have
No trembling hearts, not fall into an ague,
Like Children at the sight of a portent:
But like a Rock when wind and waves go highest,
And the insulting billowes dash against
Her ribs, be unmov'd. The King must be saluted
With other Letters, which must counterfet
The Princes character, I was his Secretary
And know the Art, malice inspire my brain
To poyson his opinion of his Son;
Ile form it cunningly.
Ha! 'tis Haraldus.
He looks sad.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not aske
My mother, 'twere a crime, but one degree
Beneath the sinfull act that gave me life
To question her, and yet to have this fright
Dwell in my apprehension, without
The knowledge of some truth, must needs distract
My poor wits quite; 'tis he, I will take boldnesse
And know the worst of him, If I be what
I am already charactred, he can
Resolved my shame too well.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How is't my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Never so ill sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Art sick?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Most dangerously.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Here, at heart, which bleeds with such a wound,
As none but you, can cure.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ile drop my soul
Into it, shew me how I may
Be thy Physitian, to restore thy blood
I will lose all mine, speak child.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This very love
Is a fresh suffering, and your readinesse
To cure my sorrow, is another wound;
You are too kind, why are you so? what is
Or can be thought in me fit to deserve it?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou dost talk wildly; to accuse me thus
For loving thee, could the world tempt me here,
And court me with her glories to forsake thee,
Thus I would dwell about thy neck, and not
Be bought from kissing thee for all her provinces:
There is a charme upon my soul to love thee,
And I must do't.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Then I must dye.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Forbid it gentler fates.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: If I could hear you wish
Me dead, I should have hope to live; although
I would not willingly deserve your anger,
By any impious deed, you do not know
What comfort it would be to heare you curse me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He's mad; Haraldus, prethee do not talk so.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Or if you think a curse too much to help me,
Yet rail upon me, but do't heartily, and call me

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Vilaine, or Bastard, sir,
The worst is best from you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou dost amaze me.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Will you not for me?
Then for my mothers sake if you do love her,
Or ever did esteem her worth your friendship,
Let me entreat you draw your sword, and give me
Something to wear in blood upon my bosome;
Write but one letter of your name upon
My brest, Ile call you father, by your love;
Do something that may make me bleed a little.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: By that I dare not, thou hast nam'd Haraldus
A father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I but call you so, I know
You are a stranger to my blood, although
Indeed to me your great affection
Appears a wonder; nor can nature shew
More in a Parent to a child; but if
I be.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I shall blush sir to pronounce it,
There's something that concerns my mother, will not
Give it a name; yet I would be resolv'd,
That I might place my duty right; If I
Must answer to your Sonne, you may imagine
I shall no more aske you a reason, why
You have been so kind to me; and to my mother.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou hast said it, th'art mine own, 'twas nature in me,
That could not hide the actions of a Father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am your base seed then.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Stain not thy self
With such a name, but look upon thy mother
Now made a Queene.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You made her first a strumpet,
And it would aske the piety of her Sonne,
To dye upon that man that stole her honour:
Why did you so undo us? why did you
Betray my mother to this shame? or when
She had consented, why should both your lust
Curse my unsinning heart, oh I must be
For your vice scorn'd, though innocent.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: None dare—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I should not by your vertue have been sav'd,
Where shall I hide my life, I must no more
Converse with men—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou art too passionate.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I will entreat my mother we may go
Into some wildernesse, where we may find
Some Creatures that are spotted like our selves,
And live and dye there, be companion
To the wild Panther, and the Leopard, yet
They are too good for their converse, we are
By ours, defil'd, their spots do make them fair.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis time that Sueno and his companion,
Dispers'd these clouds; now to the King, with whom
If the Queens beauty keep her magick, then
Our Engine mount, and day grows bright agen.

div.head: Act. 3.
div.stage: Enter King, Queene, Olaus, Reginaldus, Aguinus, Helga.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: UNcle, I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I am not glad
To see you sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Not me?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Consorted thus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If Olaus be forgetfull of good manners,
I shall forget his years, and blood; be temperate.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There's something in your blood that will undoe
Your state and fame eternally, purge that,
You know I never flatter'd you, that woman
Will prove thy evill Genius.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Y'are too saucy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Do not I know her, was she not wife
To the Count Altomarus a weak Lord?
But too good for her, charm'd by the flattery
And magick of her face, and tongue, to dote
And Marry her, born of a private Family,
Advanc'd thus, she grew insolent, and I fear
By pride and liberty, and some trick she had,
Broke her good husbands heart.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir, you much wrong me,
And now exceed the priviledge of your birth
To injure mine.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: We all know you can plead
Your own defence, you have a womans wit,
Heaven send you equall modesty, I am plain.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It would be held an insolence in others,
And saucy boldnesse in the sacred presence
Thus of the King, to accuse, whom he hath pleas'd
To take companion of his bed; and though
It would become the justice of my cause
And honour, to desire these black aspersions
May be examin'd further, and the Author
Call'd to make proof of such a passionate language,
(Which will betray his accusation was
But envy of my fortunes) I remember
Y'are the Kings Uncle, and 'tis possible
You may be abus'd by some malicious tale
Fram'd to dishonour me, and therefore I
Beseech you humbly sir, to let this passe
But as an act in him of honest freedom,
Beside what else may give you priviledge
Being a Souldier, and not us'd to file
His language, blunt and rugged wayes of speech
Becoming your profession.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Very good!
Although we ha' not the device of tongue
And soft phrase Madam, which you make an Idol
At Court, and use it to disguise your heart,
We can speak truth in our unpollish'd words,
Thou art—

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What am I?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not the Queen.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: She is
My wife Olaus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I must never kneel to her,
Nor the good Prince your son, the hope of war,
And peaces darling, honour of our blood,
And worth a better Kingdom then he's born to—

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Must never call her Mother.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Dare you instruct him
Against his duty, leave us.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You have lost
More honour in those minutes you were married,
Then we have gain'd in months abroad, with all
Our triumph purchas'd for you with our blood;
Is this the payment, the reward for all
Our faith? when thy young Son, whose springing valour
And name, already makes the confines tremble,
Returns like young Augustus crown'd with victories;
Must a stepdame first salute him,
And tread upon his Laurel?

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Leave the Court.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: May it not prove an Hospital, 'tis i'th way
To change a title, lust and all the riots
Of licence reeling in it, by th'example
Of one should least prophane it, I am still
O laus, and your fathers brother.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Take heed
You do not talk your head off, we have Scaffolds,
But the old man raves, come my Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Then I will talke, threaten my head,
Command that Parasite that dares do most
In wickednesse, to shew himselfe your servant;
Give him his engine, and his fee for hangman,
Let him take boldness but to move one hair
That withers on my head out of his posture,
He shall have more hope to o'recome the Devil
In single duel, then to scape my fury.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Our guard.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Look you, i'le bring no danger to your person,
I love you too well; I did alwayes use
To speak, your father lik'd me near the worse.
And now I am coole againe—
You say you are married—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Then between you, and I, and let none heare us,
To make your selfe, your Son, and Kingdome prosper,
Be counsel'd to a divorce.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Not, not
To save thy soule, my sonnes life added
To thine, and lives of all the Army shall
Be divorc'd from this world first, you are my fathers
Brother, and if you love my sonne, your pupil,
So hopeful in your thoughts, teach him to come
More humbly to us, without thought to question
Our marriage, or i'le find a chastisement
For his rebellious heart, we will. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol,
sp.l: You must not; I wo'not leave him yet. Exit.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: This freedome may engage his life to danger,
He is too passionate.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He has said too much,
Ile venter speaking to him. Exit.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: He's alone, now to him.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Noble sir— I have a suit to you.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: A Courtier aske a suit of a Souldier?
You'l wear no Buffe nor Iron?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I come very impudently, and I hope to thrive
The better for't; this Gentleman my friend,
A man of quality, and in some grace with
The King, hath laid a wager with me of
Two hundred Crowns, I dare not pull a haire
From your most reverend Beard: now if you please
To give me leave, i'le win the Crownes, laugh at him,
And drink your health at supper.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: A hair from my beard?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: But one hair, if shall please you.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Come, take it.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I have pul'd three noble sir.

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: 'Twas more then your commssion, there's one
That's another, and that will make you an upright Courtier. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you—

sp.speaker: Re.
sp.l: Beg modestly hereafter, take within your bounds,
You have small beard to play upon. 'tis fit
My fist should make an answer to your wit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I have it to a hair, the cholerick Duke agen?
I am gone. Exeunt. Ent. Ol. & Aqui.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir, you have been too blame.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How dare you talk to me sir?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: 'Tis my duty, and I must tell you,
Y'ave built too much upon him as a kinsman,
And have forgot the King.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Take that for your impudence. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I have it, and I thank you.

div.stage: Enter King, reading of Letters, Queen.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: They are gone sir, but have left Prints of their fury,
The angry Duke has broke Aquinus head,
For speaking dutifully on your behalfe;
To'ther mute man of war stroke Sueno sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I heare his language humming in my head still.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Aquinus? strike so near our presence?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Nay these Souldiers will strike a man, if he doe not
Carry himselfe to a hairs breadth, I know that.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: They shall repent this impudence, look up
My dear Marpisa, there's no tempest shall
Approach to hurt thee, they have rais'd a storm
To their own ruines.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: Sir, if you'l bring me
To'th King. you shall do an office worth your labour,
I have Letters will be welcome.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: You must give
Me leave sir to present 'em from the Prince:
Most excellent, sir, my Soveraigne.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Letters? If you have a chaine of gold—

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Go hang thy selfe. Souldier gives Helga the Letters, & Exit.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I am most fortunate to present you sir
With Letters from the Prince, and if your Majestie
Knew with what zeale I tender these.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: He frowns, where's the Soldade? you'l goe my half.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Who brought these Letters? where's the messenger

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He was here but now, he's vanish'd.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Vanish thee too, and creep into the earth.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: The impudence of Children, read Marpisa,
More Letters from the proud ambitious boy,
He dares to give us precepts, and writes here,
We have too much forgot our selfe and honour,
In making thee our Queen, puts on his grace
A discontent, and sayes, the triumph he
Expected, the reward of his young merit,
Will be ungloried in our suddaine match,
And weak election.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: This was my fear.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He threatens us, if we proceed with his
Command and power i'th Army; raise new Forces
To oppose 'm, and proclaime 'm Rebels, Trayters—

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Sir, I beseech you for the generall good,
Temper your rage, these are but words of passion,
The Prince will soon be sorry for't, suspect not
His duty, rather then disgrace your Son,
Divide me from your heart, the people love him.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I'le hate him for't, Gotharus; where's Gotharus,

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: This Letter tast's of his invention,
He's active, it concerns us both. Albina.
Nay, you may forward Madam.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I beseech
Your pardon, I did hope to have found my Lord
Gotharus here.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: The King ask'd for him,
And is but new retyr'd, who I presume
If he had known of your approach, w'od not
Have gone so soon.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I have no businesse Madam
With the King.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Come do not disguise it thus,
I am covetous to know your suit;
But I am confident he will deny
You nothing, and your husband is of my
Opinion lately.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: By your goodnesse Madam,
Let me not suffer in your thoughts, I see
There is some poison thrown upon my innocence,
And tis not well done of my Lord Gotharus,
To render me to your suspition
So unhappy, 'tis too much he has withdrawn
His own heart, he will shew no seeds of charity,
To make all others scorn me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: If he do,
You can return it, but take heed your wayes
Be straite to your revenge, let not my fame
And honour be concern'd with the least wound.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I understand not what you mean.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: I cannot
Be patient, to hear the King commend
Your lip.

sp.speaker: Al
sp.l: I am betraid.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: My phrase is modest,
Do not you love the King?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes, with the duty—

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Of one that wants no cunning to dissemble
Her pride, and loose desires.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You are the Queen.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I should else tell you, 'tis ill done
To oppresse one that groans beneath the weight▪
Of griefe already, and I durst take boldnesse
To say, you were unjust.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I can
Contain no longer, take from my sad heart
What hitherto I have conceal'd, (in that
You may call me dissembler of my sorrows)
I am weary of my life, and fear not what
Your power and rage can execute; would you
Had no more guilt upon your blood, then I
Have sinne in my accounts that way, My Lord
Gotharus would not be so unkind to me.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: What's that you said so impudently Albina?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What I did think should have consum'd me here
In silence, but your injuries are mighty,
And though I do expect to have my name
In your black Register design'd for death,
To which my husband will I know consent;
I cannot thus provok'd, but speak what wounds me.
Yet here agen I shut the Casket up,
Never to let this secret forth, to spread
So wide a shame hereafter.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Thou hast wak'd
A Lyonness.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Death cannot more undo me,
And since I live an exile from my husband,
I will not doubt but you may soon prevaile,
To give my weary soul a full discharge
Some way or other; and i'th minute when
It takes her flight to an eternall dwelling,
I will forgive you both, and pray for you,
But let not your revenge be to long idle,
Least the unmeasur'd pile of my affections
Weigh me to death before your anger comes,
And so you lose the triumph of your envies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: You sha'not be forgotten, feare it not,
And but that something nearer doth concern us,
You should soon find a punishment. The King. Ex.

div.stage: Enter King, Gotharus, with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He struck Aquinus, Helga saw him bleed.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These are strange insolencies, one goe for Aquinus.
Did Olaus bring these Letters?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: No, some spirit,
For he soon vanish'd.
I have given my sonne
To the most violent men under the Planets,
These Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And they'l cling to him like Ivie,
Embrace him even to death.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Like Brees to Cattel
In summer, they'l not let him feed.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But make
Him fling, unquiet.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Most repineful, spleeny.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Ready to break the twist of his Allegiance.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Which they fret every day—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: These put upon his young blood discontents.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Dangerous—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Extreamly dangerous.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Swell him up
With the alluring shapes of rule, and Empire—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And speak his strength with a proud Emphasis;
Yours, with a faint cold-hearted voice; was ever
Such peremptory lines writ to a father?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Thy counsell, while the dangers yet aloofe.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aloofe? take heed, hils in a piece of landskip
May seem to stand a hundred leagues, yet measure,
There's but an inch in distance; oh ambition
Is a most cunning, infinite dissembler,
But quick i'th execution.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Thy counsell.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He that aspires hath no Religion,
He knows no kindred.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: I aske for thy advice.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Have you not seen a great Oke cleft asunder,
With a small wedge cut from the very heart
Of the same tree?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: It frights me to apply it;
Oh my mis-fortune, this is torment, not
A cure. Enter Aquinus

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Aquinus, Speak him gently sir,
And leave me to encourage him in a service
Worth his attempt, and needful to your safety.
Noble Aquinus, our good King has sence
Of the affront you suffered from his Uncle,
And as he is inform'd, for speaking but
The duty of a subject.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: This is true sir,
I wear his bloody favour still, I never
Took any blow so long on trust.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I know thy spirit's daring, and it shal become
My justice to reward thy suffering;
A storm now hovers o're my Kingdom,
When the aire is clear, and our sky fair agen,
Expect, nay challenge, we shall recompence
What thou hast suffer'd for us, with a bounty
Worth all thy merits, i'th mean time apply
Thy selfe to my Gotharus, and be counsel'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: My duty.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Th'hast no alliance to my blood;
Yet if thou think'st I do not flatter thee,
I feel a friendly touch of thy dishonour,
The blow, 'twas not well done of Duke Olaus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You great men think you may do what you please,
And if y'have a mind to pound us in a morter
We must obey.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That law is none of natures,
And this distinction of birth and royalty
Is not so firme a proofe, but there are men
Have swords to pierce it through, and make the hearts
Of those that take this priviledge from their blood,
Repent they were injurious.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: My sword
Was quiet when he beat me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: He did not, could not beat thee.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: 'Twas worse, he cudgel'd me, I feel it yet,
Nor durst I strike agen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: It could not be
A tamenesse in thy spirit, but quick thought
That 'twas Olaus, not, that in thy heart
There was no will to be reveng'd, for he
Is false to nature, loves his injury,
But that there was no safety to return
Thy anger on his person.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Y'are i'th right,
That frighted me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: For he is not reveng'd,
That kills his enemy and destroyes himselfe,
For doing his own justice, therefore men
That are not slaves, but free, these we receive
Born, and bred Gentlemen in fair employments,
That have, and dare bid high agen for honour,
When they are wrong'd by men 'bove them in title,
As they are thought worthy a personall wound,
In that are rais'd and level'd with the injurer;
And he that shall provoke me with his weapon,
By making me his enemy, makes me equal,
And on those terms I kill him: But there is
Another caution to wise men, who ought
To cast and make themselves secure, that when
They have return'd full payment for their sufferings
In fame, they may be safe without a guard.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: That sir is the prudence.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yet I can direct thee
To be reveng'd with safety unto this,
What if I add therein, thou shalt do service
That will oblige the common-wealth, that groans
With fear of innovation, and make
The King thy friend by one expence of courage;
And having nam'd the king thus, it must make
Thy thoughts secure from future losse, and in
The present act no danger.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: Sir, be cleere,
Make good what you have promis'd,
And see if I be frighted, I have help'd
Many give up the ghost.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Olaus us'd
Thee basely, how much would the Kingdome suffer
If he were dead and laid into his Tombe,
Perhaps a year sooner then nature meant,
To make his bones fit.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I dare kill him sir,
If I were sure the King would pardon me,
That in my own revenge, and any other
Whom he calls enemy without exception,
To this I am bound in conscience; sir, there needs
No conjuration for this, nor art
To heighten me, let me but hear the King
Will have it, and secure me.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thou deserv'st him,
And maist a statue, for our great deliverer,
Yet, now I have thought better on't, we may
Save trouble in Olaus Tragedy,
And kill him through another.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: One that
Sits heavier on the Kings heart, and dwels in't
Such a disease, as if no resolute hand
Cure him.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I'le be his Chyrurgion.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: When I name him,
One that has had no will to advance thee
To thy deserts in wars, for all thy former
And thy late services, rewarded with
A dull command of Captain, but incenst
By Olaus now who rules his heart, lesse hope
To be repair'd in fortune.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let him be the Prince.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis he.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: It honours my attempt;
And while his father holds him disobedient,
I think him lesse then subject.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Disobedient? look there. Shews a Letter.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: This is the Princes hand.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But read his heart.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Impious! above the reach
Of common faith.
I am satisfied, he must not live; the way:
They would not trust me with his cup to poyson it,
Shew me the way— the King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Lets study. Enter King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: You have a faithful servant in Gotharus.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Upon his wisdome we depend.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I have it,
He shall dye like a Souldier, thus— Whispers.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Their malice
Doth onely aime at me, and if you please
To give me up a sacrifice to their fury.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Not for a thousand Sons, my life and honors
Must sit with thine Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: This act shall make thee great, the King and Queene
Look cheerefull royal sir, and think of honour
To crown the merit of this Captain, let
No trouble shake a thought, he will deserve
Your bosome sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: He shall possesse it; how my Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Pray leave it to me, it is not ripe yet for your knowledge sir.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: We'l trust thee, come Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Dearest Madam! come Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I attend your Lorship. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Haraldus, Sueno, Helga, at a banquet.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My Lord, you honour us.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If we knew how to expresse our duties.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: No more ceremony,
Your loves engage me, if some discontents
Make me not seem unpleasant; yet I must
Confesse I was more prompted to th'acceptance,
In hope to cure a melancholly.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.l: With your pardon,
It does too much usurpe on your sweet nature,
But if your Lordship please, there is a way
To banish all those thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would call him doctor
That could assure me that.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I am of his
Opinion sir, and know the best receipt
I'th world for sadness.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Prethee what?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Good wine.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have heard 'em talk so, If I thought there were
That operation—

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Try sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: My humble duty— 'tis excellent wine!

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Helga.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Your Lordships servant.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis pleasant. Drinkes.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: It has spirit, will you please
Another tryall, that prepares more sweetness,
Health to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: With your pardon, fill to me,
Your grace should have it last.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: She is my mother.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: She is our royall mistress, heaven preserve her;
Does not your Lordship feel more inclination
To mirth, there is no spell 'gainst sorrow, like
Two or three cups of wine.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Nothing believ't,
Will make your soul so active, take it liberally.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I dare not trust my brain.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You never tryed.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: You'l never know the pleasure then of drinking
I have drunk my selfe into an Emperour.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: In thy own thoughts.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Why is't not rare, that wine
Taken to the extent, should so delightfully
Possess the imagination, I have had my Queens
And Concubines—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Fine fancies.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The Kings health,
Give me't in greater volum, these are acorns
Sueno to thee, I'me sprightly but to look out.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: What rare things will the flowing vertue raise,
If but, the sight exalt you? to your grace,
The Kings health.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Let it come, i'le trespasse once.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That smile became you sir.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: This Cup doth warm me, Drinkes.
Methinks I could be merry.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Will your grace have any musick?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Strike lustily. Musicke.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have begun no health yet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Now you must honour us.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Health to the Prince.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That is your title sir,
As you are Sonne to a Queene,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My father was no King, father? i'le drown
The memory of that name. Drinkes.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: The Prince Turgesius health.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: He's not far off
By the Court Computation— happinesse now
To Prince Haraldus mistress.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: With devotion.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Alas, I am too young to have a mistress.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: Sir, you must crown it.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: These are complements

div.stage: At Court, where none must want a drinking mistress.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Methinks loud musick should attend these Healths—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: So, shall we dance? Drinkes.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: We want Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am as light, thou shalt go for a Lady.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Shall I? Dance.
Is not this better, then to sigh away
Our spirits now?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'me hot.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: A cup of wine is the most naturall cooler.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: You are my Physitians Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Make it a health to my Lord Gotharus. Drinks:
I'le pledge it as heartily as he were my father.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Whose father? Throws wine in Sueno's face.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Mine, I said.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Cry mercy.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis but so much wine lost, fill't again.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I'le drink no more.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: What think you of a song? Song.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: A catch, to't boyes.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Shall we to bed Gentlemen?
I did not sleep last night.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: If your Grace
Desire to sleep, there's nothing to prepare it
Like to'ther cup.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: A health to both your Mistresses. Drinks

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: You do us grace.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: There's hope of his conversion▪

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am nos well, what wheels are in my brains?
Philosophy affirms the earth moves not,
'Tis here me thinks confuted, Gentlemen,
You must be faine to lead me to some couch,
Where I may take a nap, and then i'le thank you,
I'le come agen to morrow.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Every day
For a twelve-month.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: That will make you a good fellow. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Prince Turgesius, Reginaldus, Souldiers marching, Olaus meets, they salute and whisper.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: You tell me wonders.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis all truth, we must
Stand on our guard, 'tis well we are provided.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Is it not some device to make us feare,
That at our entertainment we may find
Our joyes more spatious.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There is some device in't.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: It is not possible a father should
Be so unkind to his own blood and honour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: My life was threatned.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Who durst threaten it?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The King your father.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Oh say not so good sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And if you please him not with your behaviour,
Your head may be soon humbled to the axe,
And sent a token of his love, to your stepdame
The Queen, I trifle not.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: For what sinnes
Hath angry heaven decreed to punish Norway,
And lay the Scene of wrath in her own bowels?
I did suspect when none came forth to meet
Our victory, to have heard of some mis-fortune,
Some prodigies engendring: down with all
Our pride of war, the Garlands we bring home
Will but adorne us for the sacrifice;
And while our hairs are deck'd with flowers and ribbands,
We shall but march more gloriously to death.
Are all good women dead within the Kingdom,
There could be found none worth my fathers love,
But one whose fame and honour is suspected?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Woulst they were but suspected.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Marpisa?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Her preferment was no doubt
Gotharus act, for which 'tis whisper'd,
She payes him fair conditions, while they both
Case up the Kings eyes, or confine him to
Look through such cunning opticks as they please.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I'le have his heart.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But how will you come by't?
He's safe in the Kings bosome, who keeps warm
A serpent, till he find a time to gnaw
Out his preserver.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: We had dyed with honour
By the Enemies sword, something might have been read
In such a fall, as might have left no shame
Upon our story, since 'tis chance of war,
Not want of valour, gives the victory;
This ship-wracks all, and eates into the soule
Of all our fame, it withers all the deeds
Is owing to our name.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: Health to the Prince,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Cortes, welcome, what news?

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: These Letters will inform his highness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Sent, from the King Cortes? has he thought upon't?
Are we considerable at last, and shall
The Lady Geugaw, that is pearch'd upon
His throne, be counsell'd not to take too much
Upon her? will Gotharus give us leave
To be acquainted with the King agen? ha!

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.l: These Letters came sir from Aquinus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How?
I hope he mentions not the broken pate
I gave him, and complains on't to the Prince,
I may be apt to make him an amends
With such another.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Read, I am planet-stroke, cursed Gotharus!
What would the traytor have?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis here, I take it, he would have you sent
Yonder, and has tooke order with Aquinus
For your conveyance hence, at both their charges;
But now you know the plot, you wo' not trust
Your life as he directs.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Not trust Aquinus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You are desperate, hark you, I do suspect him,
And I ha' cause, I broke his head at Court
For his impertinent counsell, when I was
In passion with the King, you sha'not trust him,
This may be cunning to revenge himselfe,
I know he has a spirit, come you sha' not
Be cheated of your life, while I have one
To counsell you.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Uncle, I am unmov'd,
He is a Souldier, to that name and honour
I'le trust a Princes life, he dares not be
A traytor.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I have read that one Prince was
So credulous, and scap'd, but Alexander,
Though he were great, was not so wise a Gentleman,
As heaven in that occasion might have made him,
The valiant confidence in his doctor, might
Ha' gnawn his bowels up, and where had been
My gallant Macedonian? come you shall
Consider on't.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I am resolv'd already,
March to the City, every thought doth more
Confirm me, passion will not let you see,
Good Uncle with your pardon, the true worth
And inside of Aquinus, he is faithfull,
Should I miscarry, 'tis my single life,
And 'tis obedience to give up our breath,
When fathers shall conspire their Childrens death

div.head: Act. 4.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: YOu may surrender up your Crown, 'twill shew
Brave on Turgesius Temples, whose ambition
Expects it.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Nay Gotharus—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Has my care
Cast to prevent your shame, how to preserve
The glories you possesse, by cutting off
A Canker that would eat into your trunck,
And hinder your fair growth, and do you make
A scruple to be cured?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I did but mention,
And nature may excuse, he is my son.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The more your danger, when he dares be impious,
The forfeit of his duty in this bold
And hostile manner to affright your subjects,
And threaten you with articles, is already
The killing of your honour, and a treason
Nature abhors, a guilt heaven trembles at,
And you are bound in care of your own province,
To shew your justice, and not be partiall
To your own blood; but let your Kingdome suffer,
Her heart be torn by civill Wars; 'tis none
Of mine, and let him in the blood of many
Fathers, be made a King, your King; and you
That now command, be taught obedience,
Creep to your child, exchange your pallace for
A prison, and be humbled till you think
Death a preferment, I have but a life—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Which I will cherish, be not passionate,
And I consent to all thou hast contained;
Thou art my friend.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I would be sir, your honest Chyrurgion,
And when you have a Gangrene in your limb,
Not flatter you to death, but tell you plainly
If you would live, the part so poyson'd must be
Cut from your body.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: And I wo'not shake
With horror of the wound, but meet my safety
And thank my best preserver; but art sure
Aquinus will be resolute?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Suspect not,
He is my Creature.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The Prince your Sonne—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Is a bold Traytor.
And they are Rebels joyne with him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: What of the Prince Hormenus?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He is very near the City with his Army.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Are the walls fortified?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They are?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: We wo'not trust him, nor the Ruffian
Olaus, that Incendiary.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The Queen. Enter Marpisa.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: There are more wounds in those sad accents,
Then their rebellion can give my Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: My boy, my child, Haraldus.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is sick, is dying sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Forbid it heavens, he was in health—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: But if I mean to see him
A live, they say I must make hast,
The comforts of my life expire with him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The Devils up in arms, and fates conspire
Against us.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Mischiefes tumble like waves upon us.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sir, It will be necessary
You lend your person to direct, what shall
Be further done i'th City, Aquinus hath
Charge of the Gate and Walls, that offer
The first view to the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He is trusty, and
A daring Souldier; what at stand Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I was thinking of the Queen sir, and Haraldus,
And grieve for the sweet child.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Some feaver, would my
Son were in his state, but soon we shall
Conclude his destiny, if Aquinus prosper;
But to the walls.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I attend, my very soule
Is in a sweat, Hormenus.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I wait on you. Exeunt:

div.stage: Enter Prince Turgesius, Olaus, Cortes, Reginaldus, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The Gates are shut against us Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let our Engines
Teare 'em, and batter down the walls.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good Uncle,
Your counsell I obey'd i'th wars abroad,
We did there fight for honour, and might use
All the most horrid formes of death to fright
Our enemies, and cut our way to victory:
But give me leave to tell you sir, at home
Our conquest will be losse, and every wound
We give our Country, is a crimson teare
From our own heart, they are a viperous brood
Gnaw through the bowels of their parent, I
Will rather dye without a monument,
Then have it bear my name, to have defaced
One heap of stones.

div.stage: Enter Gotharus on the walls, Ho. Aqui.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Gotharus on the walls?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Hormonus and Aquinus? now a speech,
And 'twere at Gallowes would become him better.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Thus from my master, to the Prince of Norway,
We did expect, and had prepar'd to meet
Your victory with triumphs, and with Garlands
Due to your fate and valours, entertain'd you▪
Nor has your Army sacrific'd so many
Warm drops of blood, as we have shot up prayers
That you might prosper, and return the pledge
Of all our hope and glory. But when pride
Of your own fames, and conquest in a war,
Hath poyson'd the obedience of a Sonne,
And tempted you to advance your sword, new bath'd
In enemies blood 'gainst your Countries bosome;
Thus we receive you, and declare your pietie,
And faith lost to your Country, and your Father.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: My Lord, all this concerns not me, we have
But done our dutyes, and return to lay
The Trophies at his feet, whose justice did
Make us victorious more then our own valour,
And now without all titles but his sonne,
I dare hells accusation, to blast
My humble thoughts.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Sir, give us leave to feare,
Not your own nature, calme as the soft aire,
When no rude wind conspires a mutiny—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Leave Rethorique, and to'th point, why do not
The Gates spread to receive us? and your joyes
Shoot up in acclamations? I would have
Thy house give good example to the City▪
And make us the first-born fire.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Good heaven knows,
How willingly I would sacrifice my selfe,
To do a grateful service to the Prince:
And I could wish my Lord, you were less passionate,
And not inflame his Highnesse gentle spirit
To these attempts.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am ignorant Gotharus
Of what you mean, where is the King my father?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Where a sad father is, to know his Sonne
Bring arms against his life.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: How now Aquinus,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dare you be saucy?
O that Gentleman
Is angry, his head akes with the remembrance of
My Truncheon.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: 'Twas a valiant act,
And did become the greatness of Olaus,
Who by the priviledge of his birth, may do
A wrong and boast it.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Shall these Groomes affront us?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Have you commission to be thus insolent,
They do not know us?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yes, and in our hearts
Bleed, that our fears of your unjust demand,
Compell us to this separation.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Demands? is it injustice for a Sonne
To aske his fathers blessing? by thy duty
Gotharus, I command thee, tell my father
His Sonne desires access, let me but speak with him.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I have not in your absence sir neglected,
What did become my service to your highnesse,
To take his anger off.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: What Riddles this?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: But let me with a pardon tell your Grace,
The Letters that you sent, were not so dutyfull,
You were to blame, to chide and Article
So with a King and Father; yet I said,
And pawn'd my Conscience 'twas no act of yours,
I mean intyre, but wrought and form'd by some
Rash spirits, to corrupt you with ambition,
Feeding your youth with thought of hasty empire
To serve their ends, whose counsell all this while
Did starve that sweetness in you we all hop'd for.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Devices! more devices!

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I am amaz'd,
And if the King will not vouchsafe me conference,
I shall accuse thy cunning to have poyson'd
My Fathers good opinion. Enter King.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Innocence
May thus be stain'd, pray let your justice clear me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What would our Sonne?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Thus pay his filiall duty.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: 'Tis but counterfet, if you bring no thought
To force our blessing in this rude manner, how
Dare you approach? dismiss your souldiers.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not the meanest knapsack,
That were a way to bring us to the mercy
Of wolves indeed, Gotharus grinds his teeth
Already at us.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: We shall talk with you sir
Hereafter, I command thee by thy duty
Thou ow'st a father and a King, dismiss
Your Troops.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ola.
sp.l: You shall not, that were fine,
So we may run our heads into their noose,
You give away your safty.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I will not
Dispute my power, let my intreat prevaile
For their dismission.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You may dismiss
Your head and mine, and be laugh'd at, these men
Are honest, and dare fight for us.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know
Their loves, and will rewait; dear, dear Uncle.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: How he prepares his Tragedy Aquinus,
Let not thy hand shake.

sp.speaker: Aqu.
sp.l: I am resolute.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And I, for thy reward, 'tis done, the souldiers
Disperse already.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If any mischiefe follow this,
Thank your credulitie.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: May I now hope for access?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Descend Gotharus and Aquinus
To meet the Prince, while he containes within
The piety of a Son, we shall imbrace him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: When I degenerate, let me be accurst
By heaven and you.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Are you not pale to think on't.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: It puzzels me to think my father guilty.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I do not like things yet.

div.stage: As the Prince is going forth, a Pistoll is discharged within, he falls.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: O I am shot, I am murder'd.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Inhumane Traytor, villaine.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: So, so, his frend has saved my execution,
'Tis not safe for me to stay, they are both sped rarely. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: O my dear Cousin, treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: In thy own bosome, thou hast kil'd thy Sonne,
Convey his body, guard it safe, and this
Perfidious trunke i'le have it punish't
Past death, and scatter his torn flesh about
The world to affright mankind, thou art
A murthdrer, no blood of mine▪

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: 'Tis done,
And all the guilt dyes with Aquinus, falne
By Olaus sword most happily, who but
Prevented mine, this act concludes all feare.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: He was my sonne, I must needs drop a teare.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is not possible, he●●●●ch a feavor
By excess of wine? he was all temperance.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: He had a soft and tender constitution,
Apt to be inflam'd, they that are most abstemious,
Feel the disorder with more violence.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Where, who assisted him in this mis-fortune?
He had some company.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: He was invited
He sayes by Sueno, and Helga, to a banquet,
Where in their mirth, they careless of his health,
Suffered him drink too much.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: They poyson'd him,
Go apprehend the murtherers of my child,
If he recover not, their death shall wait
Upon Haraldus; but pray you tell me Gentlemen,
Is there no hope of life, have you not art
Enough to cure a feavor?

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: We find Madam,
His disease more malignant by some thought
Or apprehensions of griefe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What griefe?
Y'are all impostors, and are Ignorant
But how to kill.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Is not my mother come?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes my deare sonne, and here shall weep my selfe
Till I turne Niobe, unlesse thou givest me
Some hope of thy own life.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I would say something
Were you alone.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Leave us; now my Haraldus,
How is it with my child?

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.l: I know you love me,
Yet I must tell you truth, I cannot live,
And let this comfort you, death will not come
Unwelcome to your sonne, I do not dye
Against my will, and having my desires,
You have less cause to mourne.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What is't has made
The thought of life unpleasant, which does court
Thy dwelling here with all delights that nature
And art can study for thee, rich in all things
Thy wish can be ambitious of, yet all
These treasures nothing to thy mothers love,
