Which to enjoy thee would defer a while
Her thought of going to heaven.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Oh take heed mother, heaven
Has a spatious eare and power to punish,
Your too much love with my eternal absence,
I begge your prayers and blessing.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Th'art dejected,
Have but a will and live.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis in vaine mother.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sinke with a feavour into earth?
Look up, thou shalt not dye.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I have a wound within
You do not see, more killing then all feavors.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A wound? where? who has murder'd thee?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Gotharus—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha! furies persecute him.

sp.speaker: Ha▪
sp.l: Oh pray for him!
'Tis my duty, though he gave me death,
He is my father.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How? thy father?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: He told me so, and with that breath destroy'd me,
I felt it strike upon my spirits; mother,
Would I had neer been born!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Believe him not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Oh do not add another sinne to what
Is done already, death is charitable
To quit me from the scorn of all the world.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By all my hopes Gotharus has abus'd thee,
Thou art the lawful burden of my wombe,
Thy father, Altomarus.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Before whose spirit long since taken up,
To meet with Saints and Troops Angelicall,
I dare agen repeat thou art his Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Ten thousand blessings now reward my mother!
Speake it againe, and I may live, a stream
Of pious joy runnes through me, to my soule
Y'ave stroke a harmony next that in heaven;
Can you without a blush, call me your Child,
And sonne of Altomarus? all that's holy
Dwell in your blood for ever, speak it once,
But once agen.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Were it my latest breath,
Thou art his and mine.
Enough, my tears do flow
To give you thanks for't; I would you could resolve me
But one truth more, why did my Lord Gotharus
Call me the issue of his blood?

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.l: Alas, he thinks thou art—

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: What are those words? I am undone
Agen.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: 'Tis too late to call 'em back, he thinks I am his son—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have confess'd too much, and tremble with
The imagination, forgive me child,
And heaven, if there be mercy to a crime
So black, as I must now to quit thy fears,
Say I have been guilty off, we have been sinful,
And I was not unwilling to oblige
His active braine for thy advancement, by
Abusing his beliefe thou wer't his own,
But thou hast no such staine, thy birth is innocent,
Or may I perish ever, 'tis a strange
Confession to a child, but it may drop
A balsome to thy wound; live my Haraldus,
If not for this, to see my penitence,
And with what tears i'le wash away my sinne.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: I am no bastard then.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou art not.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But I am not found while you are lost,
No time can restore you,
My spirits faint.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Will nothing comfort thee?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: My duty to the King.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He's here. Enter King.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: How is't Haraldus?
Death sits in's face.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Give me you blessing, and within my heart
Ile pray you may have many, my soul flyes
'Bove this vain world, good Mother close mine eyes

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Never dyed so much sweetnesse in his years.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Be comforted, I have lost my sonne too,
The Prince is slaine, how now.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Justice upon the murderer of my sonne,
This villaine Helga, and his companion
Sueno, have kil'd him, where's the other?

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: Fled Madam,
But Helga does confesse he made him drunk.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: But not dead drunk, I do beseech you Madam.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Look here what your base surfet has destroy'd.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: 'Twas Sueno as well as I, my Lord Gotharus
Gave us commission for what we did.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Again Gotharus, sure he plotted this.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Hang him up straight.

sp.speaker: He.
sp.l: I left no drink behind me,
If I must dye let me have equall justice,
And let one of your guard drink me to death sir;
Or if you please to let me live till
Sueno is taken, we will drink and reele
Out of the world together.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Hence, and hang him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Sir, you must make provision against
New danger, discontent is broke into
A wild rebellion, and many of your subjects
Gather in tumults, and give out they will
Revenge the Princes death.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: This I did feare,
Where's Gotharus? O my fright, my conscience,
Has furies in't, where's Gotharus?—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not in the Court.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I tremble with confusions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am resolv'd, my joyes are all expir'd,
Nor can ambition more concern me now,
Gotharus has undone me in the death
Of my loved Sonne, his fate is next, while I
Move resolute i'le command his destiny. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How are we lost, the Prince Turgesius death
Is of no use, since 'tis unprofitable
To the great hope we stored up in Haraldus,
It was a cursed plot directed me
To raise his spirit, by those giddy engines
That have undone him, their souls reel to hell for't
How will Marpisa weep her selfe into
The obscure shades, and leave me here to grow
A statue with the wonder of our fate.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Do not trouble me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Although
I am not partner of your joyes or comfort,
Yet let your cruelty be so mindfull of me
I may divide your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Would thy sufferings
Could ease me of the weight, I would
Empty my heart of all that's ill, to sinke thee,
And bury thee alive, thy sight is hatefull,
Aske me not why, but in obedience
Fly hence into some wildernesse. The Queeen.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Great Queen, did any sorrow lade my bosome,
But what does almost melt it for Haraldus,
Your presence would revive me, but it seems
Our hopes and joyes in him grew up so mighty,
Heaven became jealous, we should undervalue
The bliss of th'other world, and build in him
A richer Paradice.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have mourn'd already
A mothers part, and fearing thy excess
Of griefe, present my selfe to comfort thee,
Tears will not call him back, and 'twill become us
Since we two are the world unto our selves,
(Nothing without the circle of our arm's
Precious and welcome) to take heed our griefe
Make us not over soon, like him that dead,
And our blood useless.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Were you present Madam,
When your Sonne dyed?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I was.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: And did you weepe;
And wish him live, and would not heaven at
Your wish, return his wandering Ghost agen?
Your voyce should make another out of Atomes;
I do adore the harmony, and from
One pleasant look, draw in more blessings
Then death knows how to kill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He is recovered from his passion.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Whats this? ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Here, like a sudden winter
Struck on my heart, I am not well o'th sudden, ha?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Lord, make use of this, 'tis Cordial,
sp.stage: Gives him a box of poyson.
sp.l: I am often subject to these passions,
And dare not walk without this Ivory box
To prevent danger, they are pleasant,
'Tis a most happy opportunity.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Let me present my thanks to my preserver,
And kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Our lips will meet more lovingly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My heart will break.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Your Lady, we are betray'd,
She see us kiss, and I shall hate her for't.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Does this offend your vertue?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Y'are merciless,
You shall be a less▪ Tyrant sir to kill me,
Injurious Queen!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Shall I be here affronted?
I shall not think Gotharus worth my love,
To let her breath forth my dishonour, which
Her passion hath already dared to publish,
Nor wanted she before an impudence
To throw this poyson in my face.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I'le tame her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I wo'not curse you Madam, but you are
The Cruel'st of all woman kind,
I am prepared to meet your tyrannies.

div.stage: Enter Gotharus with a Pistol, at the other doore, a servant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: My Lord,
We are undone, the common people are
In arms, and violently assault our house,
Threatning your Lordship with a thousand deaths,
For the good Prince, whose murther they exclaime
Contriv'd by you.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The frends of hell will shew more mercy to me,
Where shall I hide me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Alas they'l kill me too.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.l: There's no staying, they have broke the wall of the first Court,
Down at some window sir.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Helpe me, O help me, I' me me lost.
Within —Down with the doors,
This way, this way. Enter Rebels.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: He that first moves this way
Comes on his death, I can dispatch but one,
And take your choise.
Alas good Madam, we do not come to trouble you
You have sorrow enough, we would talk
With my Lord your pagan husband.
I, I, where is he?
That Traytor.
Murderer of our Prince.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Y'are not well informed,
Aquinus kill'd the Prince.
But by my Lords correction
We know his heart, and do meane to eat it.
Therefore let him appeare, knock down the Lady
You with the long bill.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How dare you runne the hazard of your lives
And fortunes, thus like out-laws, without authority
To break into our houses, when you have done,
What fury leads you to 't, you will buy too dear
Repentance at the Gallows.
Hang the Gallowes, and give us my Lord your husband.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He's escap'd Madam, now they may search.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: But where's the Queene, she must not be betrai'd.
This way, this way, he got out of a window,
And leap'd a wall, follow, follow.
Within —Follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: O my poor Gotharus.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Madam, you are secure, though you pursued
My death, I wish you safety,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have been
Too cruell, but my fate compell'd me to't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am become the extreamest of all miseries.
Oh my unhappy Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Helga is hanged, what will become of me?
I think I were best turn Rebel, there's no hope
To walk without a guard, and that I shall not
Want to the Gallowes, heathen Halberdiers
Are used to have a care, and do rejoyce
To see men have good ends.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am pursued.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: My Lord Gotharus? worse and worse, oh for a mist before his eyes.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: You sha'not betray me sir.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Hold my Lord, I am your servant, honest Sueno.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Sueno, off with that case, it may secure me,
Quickly, or—

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, you shall command my skin,
Alas poor Gentleman, I'm glad I have it
To do your Lordship service.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Nay, your beard too?

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Yes, yes, any thing:
Alas my good Lord, how comes this?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Leave your untimely prating, help,
You'l not betray me.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: I'le first be hanged.
Within— Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Hell stop their throats; so, so, now thy reward

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: It was my duty, troth sir I will have nothing.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Yes, take that, and that, for killing of Haraldus. Wounds him.
Now I'm sure you will not prate.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: O murther.
Within— Follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I cannot scape, oh help invention.

div.stage: He bloodies himselfe with Sueno's blood, and falls down as dead.

sp.l: This way they say he went, what's he?
One of our company I think,
Who kil'd him?
I know not.
Lets away, if we can find that Traytor,
He shall pay for all▪
Oh that I had him here, I'de teach him—
This way, this way.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh.
Stay, There's one groans.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh—
Nay 'twas here abouts, another dead?
He has good cloathes, Gotharus? the very cur.
'Tis Gotharus, I have seen the dog.
'Tis he, 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Oh. Exit Gotha.
Now 'tis not he, if thou canst speak my friend—

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.l: Gotharus murdered me, and shifted cloathes,
He cannot be far off, oh.
Thats he that lyes dead yonder, O that he were
Alive againe, that we might kill him one after another.
He's gone:
The Devill he is, follow, follow.
This way, he cannot scape us, farewell friend,
i'le doe thee a courtecy.
Follow, follow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: So, so, in this disguise you may to'th Army,
Who though they seem to scatter, are to meet
By my directions, honest Aquinus, you
You wait on the Prince, but sir— Whispers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Were you not wounded?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: I prepared a privie Coat, for that I knew Gotharus
Would have been too busie with my flesh else,
But he thinks I'm slaine by the Duke, and hugges
His fortune in't.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: You'l follow.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And bring you news, perhaps the Rabble are
In hot pursuite after the Polititian,
He cannot scape them, they'l teare him like
So many hungry Mastives. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I could wish they had him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Lose no time, Cortes stay you with me,
Not that I think my house will want your guard.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Command me sir.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Whas ever such a practise by a father,
To take away his Sonnes life?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I would hope he may not be so guilty, yet I know not
How his false terrors multiplied by the Art
Of this Gotharus may prevaile upon him,
And win consent.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Aquinus has been faithfull,
And deceived all their treasons, but the Prince
Is still thought dead, this empty Coffine shall
Confirme the people in his funerall,
To keep their thoughts revengeful,
Within .Follow, follow—
Till we are possest of him that plotted all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The cry draws this way,
They are excellent Blood-hounds.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: As you are men, defend me from the rage
Of the devouring multitude; I have
Deserv'd your anger, and a death, but let not
My limbs inhumanely be torne by them,
O save me.
Within .Follow, foll—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Blest occasion.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: I am forced to take your house, and now implore
Your mercy, but to rescue me from them,
And be your own revenger, yet my life
Is worth your preservation for a time,
Do it, and i'le reward you with a story
You'l not repent to know.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You cannot be safe here,
Their rage is high, and every doore
Must be left open to their violence,
Unlesse you will obscure you in this Coffin,
Prepared for the sweet Prince that's murder'd,
And but expects his body which is now imbalming.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: That, O y'are charitable.
Within .Follow, fol—

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Their noise is Thunder to my soul,
So, so.

sp.speaker: Ola.
sp.l: How now Gentlemen, what means this Tumult,
Do you know that I possesse this dwelling?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.l: Yes my Lord,
But we were told my Lord Gotharus entred,
And we beseech you give him to our justice,
He is the common enemy, and we know he killed the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You may search if you please,
He can presume of small protection here,
But I much thank you for your loyalties,
And service to the Prince, whose bloodless ruines
Are there, and do but wait when it will please
His father to reverse a cruell sentence,
That keeps him from a buriall with his Ancestors,
We are forbid to do him rights of funerall.
How, not bury him?
Forbid to bury our good Prince? we'l bury him,
And see what Priest dare not assist us.
Not bury him? we'l do't, and carry his body in triumph
Through the City, and see him laid i'th great Tombs
Not bury our Prince? that were a jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis their love and duty.
We'l pull the Church down, but we'l have our will.
Deare Prince, how sweet he smels.
Come Countrymen march, and see who dares
Take his body from us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You cannot helpe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They'l bury him alive.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He's in a fright.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: So may all Traytors thrive. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. 5.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: OH I am lost, and my soul bleeds to thinke
By my own dotage upon thee.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I was curst
When I first saw thee, poor wind-shaken King!
I have lost my Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Thy honour impious woman,
Of more price then a Sonne, or thy own life,
I had a sonne too, whom my rashness sent
To another world, my poor Turgesius,
What sorcery of thy tongue and eyes betraid me?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I would I had been a Basilisk, to have shot
A death to thy dissembling heart, when I
Gave my selfe up thy Queen; I was secure,
Till thou with the temptation of greatness
And flattery, didst poyson my sweet peace,
And shall thy base feares leave me now a prey
To Rebels?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I had been happy to have left
Thee sooner, but be gone, get to some wildernesse
Peopled with Serpents, and engender with
Some Dragon like thy self.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Dost laugh thou prodigie? thou shame of woman?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, and despise thee dotard, vex till thy soul
Break from thy rotten flesh, I will be merry
At thy last groan.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: O my poor boy! my sonne!
His wound is printed here, that false Gotharus,
Your wanton Goat I feare, practis'd with thee
His death.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'Twas thy own act and timerous heart, in hope
To be secure, I glory in the mention
Thou murderer of thy sonne.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Oh sir, if ever, stand upon your guard,
The Army which you thought scattered and broke,
Is grown into a great and threatning body,
Lead by the Duke Olaus your lov'd Uncle,
Is marching hither, all your subjects fly to him.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Curse on thy spleene, is this a time for laughter,
When horror should afflict thy guilty soule?
Hence mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not to obey thee, (shadow of a King)
Am I content to leave thee, and but I wo'not
Prevent thy greater sorrow and vexation,
Now I would kill thee coward.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I, I, Who comes to your rescue?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Are all fled?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Slaves do it naturally.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Canst thou hope to scape?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I am mistress of my fate, and do not feare
Their inundation, their Army comming,
It does prepare my triumph, they shall give
Me libertie, and punish thee to live.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Undone, forsaken, miserable King!

div.stage: Enter Prince, Olaus, Cortes, Aquinus, Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Worthy Aquinus, I must honour thee,
Thou hast preserv'd us all, thy service will
Deserve a greater monument then thanks.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Thank the Duke, for breaking o' my pate.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I know 'twas well bestow'd, but we have now
Proof of thy honest heart.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: But what with your highness favour, do you meane
To do with your father?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Pay my duty to him,
He may be sensible of his cruelty,
And not repent to see me live.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But with your favour, something else must be
Considered, there's a thing he calls his Queen,
A limbe of Lucifer, she must be rosted
For the Armies satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: They'l ne'r digest her,
The Kings hounds may be kept hungry
Enough perhaps, and make a feast upon her.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I wonder how the rabble will bestow
The Coffin.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why, they'l bury him alive
I hope.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Did they suppose my body there?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I'm sorry, he will fare so much the better,
I would the Queen were there to comfort him,
Oh they would smell, and sweat together rarely.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He dare as soon be damn'd as make a noise,
Or stirre, or cough.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: If he should sneeze.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Tis his best course to go into the ground
With silence.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: March on, stay, what Trumpets that?

div.stage: Enter Rebels with a Trumpet before the Coffin marching.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They are no enemies, I know the Coffin.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What rusty Regiment ha' we here?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: They are going to bury him, he's not yet discovered;
Oh do not hinder 'em, 'tis a work of charity:
Yet now I do consider better on't,
You may do well to shew your selfe, that may
Be a meanes to waken the good Gentleman,
And make some sport before the rascall smell,
And yet he's in my nostrill, he has perfum'd
His box already.

sp.speaker: Om. Reb.
sp.l: 'Tis he, 'tis he, the Prince alive! hey.

div.stage: They see the Prince throw downe the Coffin, and runne to kneele and embrace him.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What would he give but for a knife to cut
His own throat now?

sp.speaker: Om. Rebel.
sp.l: Our noble Prince alive?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: That owes himselfe to all your loves.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: What? what trinkets ha' you there?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.l: The Duke Olaus told us 'twas the Princes body,
Which we resolv'd to bury with magnificence.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: So it appeares.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: 'Tis better as it is.

sp.speaker: 2. Reb.
sp.l: There's something in't, my shoulder is still sensible,
Lets search, stand off—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now do you sent him Gentlemen? he wo'd forgive
The hangman to dispatch him out o'th way;
Now will these Masties use him like a Cat,
Most dreadfull Rogues at an execution:
Now, now.

sp.speaker: 1. Reb.
sp.l: 'Tis a man, ha Gotharus, the thing we whet our teeth for.

sp.speaker: Om. Reb.
sp.l: Out with the traytor, and with the murderer, hey, drag him.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I told you.

sp.speaker: 1 Reb.
sp.l: Hold, know your dutie fellow renagades,
We do beseech thee high and mighty Prince,
Let us dispose of what we brought, this traytor
He was given us by the Duke, fortune has
Thrown him into our teeth.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: And they'l devour him.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: We beseech your highness.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I doe acknowledge it, good sir grant their boone,
And try the Caniballs.
Ile have an arme.
Ile have a legge, I am a Shoomaker,
His shinbone may be useful.
I want a signe, give me his head.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Stay, let's first see him, is he not stifled?
I had rather my wife were speechlesse.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The Coffin sir was never close.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He does not stirre.
We'l make him stir, hang him, he's but asleepe.
He's dead, hum.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dead? Then the Devill is not so wise as I took him.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: He's dead, and has prevented all their fury.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: He was not smother'd, the Coffin had aire enough.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: He might ha' liv'd to give these Gentlemen some content.

sp.speaker: 1 Reb.
sp.l: Oh let us teare his limbs.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Let none use any violence to his body,
I feare he has met reward above your punishment.
Let me have but his clothes.
He is a Taylor.
Onely to cut out a sute for a Traytor by 'em,
Or any man, my conscience would wish hang'd.
Let me have a button for a relique—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No more.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: There is some mystery in his death.
The King? obscure a little nephew—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: To whom now must I kneel? where is the King?
For I am nothing, and deserve to be so,
Unto you Uncle must I bow, and give
My Crown, pray take it, with it give me leave
To tell you, what it brings the hapless wearer,
Beside the outside glory: for I am
Read in the miserable fate of Kings.
You thinke it glorious to command, but are
More subject then the poorest payes you dutie,
And must obey your fears, your want of sleepe,
Rebellion from your Vassals, wounds even from
Their very tongues, whose quietnesse you sweat for,
For whose dear health you waste, and fright your
Strength to palenesse, and your blood into a frost.
You are not certaine of a friend or servant,
To build your faith upon, your life is but
Your subjects murmur, & your death their sacrifice;
When looking past your selfe, to make them blest
In your succession, which a wife must bring you;
You may give up your libertie for a smile
As I ha' done, and in your bosome cherish
More danger then a warre or famine brings,
Or if you have a sonne— my spirits faile me
At naming of a sonne.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh my deare father.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Ha! do not fright me in my tears, which should
Be rather blood, for yeelding to thy death,
I have let fall my penitence, though I was
Counsel'd by him whose truth I now suspect,
In the amaze and puzzle of my state—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Dear sir, Let not one thought afflict you more,
I am preserv'd to be your humble sonne still,
Although Gotharus had contriv'd my ruine,
'Twas counterplotted by this honest Captaine.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: I know not what to credit, art Turgesius?

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And do account your blessing, and forgiveness
(If I have err'd) above the whole worlds Empire▪
The Armie sir is yours.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Upon conditions—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Good sir— and all safety meant your person▪

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Right, but for your gipsie Queene, that Cocatrice.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: She's lost.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The Devil find her.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: She's false.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: That Gentleman
Jack in a Box, if he could speake,
Would cleare that point.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Forgive me gentle boy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Dear sir no more.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Best dismiss these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The Princes bountie, now you may go home;
And d'ee heare, be drunk to night, the cause requires it.

sp.speaker: R.
sp.l: We'l shew our selves good subjects.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: Heaven bless the King and Prince, and the good Duke. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: My comforts are too mighty, let me poure
More blessings on my boy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Sir, I am blest▪
If I stand faire in your opinion.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: And welcome▪ good Olaus.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Y'are deceiv'd,
I am a Ruffian, and my head must off
To please the Monkey Madam that bewitch'd you,
For being too honest to you.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: We are friends.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Upon condition that you will—

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Now have I forgot what I would have,
Oh that my Ladie Circe that transform'd you,
May be sent— whether? I ha' forgot agen,
To the Devil, any whether, far enough:
A curse upon her, she troubles me both when
I think on her, and when I forget her.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Gotharus wife, the sorrowful Albina.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If pittie dwell within your royal bosome,
Let me be heard; I come to find a husband,
Ile not believe what the hard hearted rebels
Told me, that he is dead, (they lov'd him not▪
And wish it so) for you would not permit
His murder here. You gave me, sir, to him
In holy marriage, i'le not say, what sorrow
My poor heart since hath been acquainted with,
But give him now to me, and i'le account
No blessing like that bountie; where, oh where
Is my poor Lord? none tell me? are you all
Silent, or deaf as Rocks? yet they sometimes
Do with their hollow murmurs, answer men.
This does increase my fears, none speak to me?
I aske my Lord from you sir, you once lov'd him,
He had your bosome, who hath torne him thence?
Why do you shake your head? and turn away?
Can you resolve me sir? the Prince alive?
Whose death they would revenge upon Gotharus.
O let me kisse your hand, a joy to see
You safe, doth interrupt my griefe, I may
Hope now my Lord is safe too, I like not
That melancholly gesture; why do you make
So dark your face, and hide your eies, as they
Would shew an interest in sorrow with me.
Where is my Lord? can you or any tell me
Where I may find the comfort of mine eies,
My husband; or but tell me that he lives,
And I will pray for you— then he is dead
Indeed I feare.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Poor Ladie.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Madam be comforted.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why that's well said, I thank you gentle sir,
You bid me be comforted, blessing on you,
Shew me now reason for it, tell me something
I may believe.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Madam, your husbands dead.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And did you bid me sir be comforted
For that? oh you were cruel▪ dead? who murdered him?
For though he lov'd not me in life, I must
Revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Alas you cannot.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No?
Will not heaven heare me think you? for i'le pray
That horror may pursue the guiltie head
Of his black murderer, you doe not know
How fierce and fatall is a widowes curse;
Who kil'd him? saie.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: We know not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Y'are unjust.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Pursue not sorrow with such inquisition
Ladie.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not I? who hath more interest?

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: The knowledge of what circumstance depriv'd him
Of life, will not availe to his return;
Or if it would, none here know more, then that
He was brought hither dead in that inclosure.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: In that Coffin Ladie.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Was it charitie
Made this provision for him? oh my Lord
Now may I kisse thy wither'd lip, discharge
Upon thy bosome a poor widowes tears;
There's something tempts my heart to shew more dutie,
And wait on thee to death, in whose pale dresse
Thou dost invite me to be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Remove that Coffin.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Y'are uncharitable;
Is't not enough that he is rob'd of life
Among you, but you'l rob me of his bodie?
Poor remnant of my Lord; I have not had
Indeed so many kisses a great while,
Pray do not envie me, for sure I sha'not
Die of this surfet, he thought not I was
So neare to attend him in his last and long
Progresse, that built this funerall tenement
Without a roome for me; the sad Albina
Must sleepe by her dead Lord, I feel death coming,
And as it did suspect, I durst not look
On his grim visage, he has drawn a curtaine
Of mist before my eies.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Look to the Ladie.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Look to Albina, our Physitians,
There is not so much vertue more i'th Kingdome:
If she survive this passion, she is worth
A Prince, and I will court her as my blessing.
Say, is there hope?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: There is.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Above your lives preserve her.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: With our best art and care.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She has almost made me woman too; but
Come to other businesse.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: Is not this the Queene?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: The Queen of hell, give her no hearing, but
Shoot, shoot her presently without more repentance,
There is a leacherous Devil in her eye,
Give him more fire, his hell's not hot enough,
Now shoot.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Be temperate good sir.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Nay let his cholerick highness be obey'd.

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: She is shot-free.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The Prince alive? where is Gotharus?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your friend that was.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is confest.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Your Stallion.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He has more titles sure.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Let but some strangle her in her own haire.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The office will become a noble hangman.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Whore—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ile not spend my breath upon thee,
I have more use on't, does Gotharus live?

sp.speaker: Aq.
sp.l: You may conjecture Madam, if you turn
Your eyes upon that object.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It has wrought then.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: What has wrought?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: His Physick sir,
For the state Megrim.
A wholsome poyson, which in his poor feares,
And fainting when the Rebels first pursu'd him,
It was my happinesse to minister
In my poor boyes revenge, kil'd by his practise.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Poyson'd.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: She is turn'd Doctor.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He becomes
Deaths pale complexion, and now I'm prepar'd

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: To die.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Prepar'd to be damn'd, a seven years killing
Will be too little.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I pitty your poor rage,
I sha'not stay so long, nor shall you have
The honour sir to kill me.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: No, let me trie.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Dost thou laugh Helcat?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, and scorne all your furies, I was not
So improvident, to give Gotharus all
My cordiall, you may trust the operation,
Here's some to spare, if any have a mind
To taste, and be assur'd, will you my Lord?
'Twill purge your choler rarely.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Ile not be your patient I thank you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This box was ever my companion,
Since I grew wicked with that Polititian,
To prevent shameful death, nor am I coy
To pleasure a friend in't.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Devils charity.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It works with method, and doth kill discreetly
Without a noise, your Mercury is a rude
And troublesome destroyer to this medicine;
I feel it gently seize upon my vitals,
'Tis now the time to steale into my heart.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Hast thou no thought of heaven?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes, I do think
Sometimes, but have not heart enough to pray;
Some vapour now rises 'twixt me and heaven,
I cannot see't, lust and ambition ruin'd me:
If greatnesse were a priviledge i'th other
World, it were a happiness to die a Queene,
I find my conscience too late, 'tis bloody,
And full of staines, oh I have been so wicked,
'Twere almost impudence to aske a pardon,
Yet for your own sakes pitty me; survive
All happie, and if you can, forgive, forgive.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Those accents yet may be repentance.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: She's dead.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Some take their bodies hence.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Let them have buriall.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: 'Tis in thee Turgesius
To dispose all, to whom I give my Crown;
Salute him King by my example.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Stay,
Upon your dutie staie, will you be traytors,
Consent your lawful King should be depos'd?
Sir, do not wound your Son, and lay so great
A staine upon his hopeful, his green honour,
I now enjoy good mens opinions,
This change will make 'em think I did conspire,
And force your resignation, were it still
By justice and your selfe, it shall not touch
My brow, till death translate you to a Kingdome
More glorious, and you leave me to succeed,
Better'd by your example in the practise
Of a Kings power and dutie.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: This obedience
Will with excess of comfort kill thy father,
And hasten that command thou wouldst decline.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Receive this Captain, and reward his faith
To you and me.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: Be Captaine of our guard.
And my good Uncle, to your eare I leave
The Souldiers, let the largesse speak our bountie
And your love.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I, this sounds well fellow Souldiers,
Trust me beside your pay for the Kings bountie.
Within Sol. Heaven preserve
The King and Prince.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Not a short prayer for me?

sp.speaker: Om. Sol.
sp.l: Heaven bless the Duke, heaven bless the Duke.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Why so, money will do much.

sp.speaker: Ki.
sp.l: A bright daie shines upon us, come my sonne,
Too long a stranger to the Court, it now
Shall bid thee wellcome, I do feel my years
Slide off, and joy drown sorrow in my tears.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-digit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a keyword in context.
